text: [Music]
[Applause]
in this video you'll see how to enable
self-service actions for Amazon
workspaces through ServiceNow if you've
made workspaces available as a product
and service now you can reduce support
overhead by setting up custom service
actions for workspaces that allow users
to perform common tasks on their own
through the ServiceNow portal
for the purposes of this demonstration
we are beginning after the initial
integration between AWS service catalog
and ServiceNow has been completed and
Amazon workspaces has been configured as
an available product before we do
anything else let's quickly review how
users can request and provision Amazon
workspaces in ServiceNow
from the ServiceNow portal end users can
access a centralized catalog of IT
services and search for what they need
by category
AWS service catalog is one of the
categories so users can request AWS
products provided by the organization
right from here
in this example Amazon workspaces is one
of the approved products
the user simply completes and submits
this order form to request the product
once the request is approved the
workspace will be provisioned from
ServiceNow in this case let's not submit
the form
instead let's look at a workspace that's
already been provisioned
to reduce support overhead you can
enable users to perform certain
self-service actions on their workspaces
using the buttons on this screen
in this case no self-service actions
have been associated with workspaces
let's see how to set one up
logged into the AWS management console
as an administrator navigate to
workspaces
here you can see a workspace running for
an example user to access the Actions
menu select the workspace
the actions you can allow users to
perform include rebooting a workspace
and even running a rebuild operation as
an example let's see how to set up AWS
to enable users to reboot their
workspaces
to get started navigate to AWS Systems
Manager and create a new automation
document for the action
provide a name for this document
next scroll down and specify the target
type for the automation document
the target is an Amazon workspace
next let's add the code to perform the
reboot of the workspace you can do that
using this editor
remove any example code and then add
code to perform the reboot you can write
this code in markdown or JSON syntax for
the purposes of this example the code
has already been written
now create the automation document
on the owned by me tab you can see the
document that was just created reviewing
the contents of this document you can
see that the first automation step
performs a reboot on a workspaces
instance
before proceeding with the configuration
let's execute this automation to test
that it works correctly
review the execution details and specify
any additional parameters as needed in
the input parameters section provide the
workspace ID of the user's instance
now execute the automation
the execution test succeeded let's
return to workspaces and refresh the
view
as you can see the workspace is
rebooting next let's navigate to the AWS
Identity and Access Management or iam
roles page
here you can see the Service Catalog
launch role which was set up to launch
services in AWS through ServiceNow as
part of the initial integration
this role has already been configured
with the appropriate policies to manage
Amazon workspaces through the AWS
Service Catalog your organization might
choose to implement launch roles
differently depending on its own
security policies and best practices
now that we've automated the action and
confirm the necessary roles we're ready
to configure AWS Service Catalog to
support the new self-service action
to do this we need to create a new
service action
select custom documents and then select
the automation that was just created
review the default values and scroll
down
in this case let's use the launch role
you saw earlier this option might be
different depending on the configuration
of your environment
now create the service action
next associate the action with the
Amazon workspaces products defined in
AWS service catalog
the product configuration and AWS is
completed now let's switch to the
ServiceNow FULFILLER view
before you can test the new service
action service now must be synced to the
AWS account rather than wait for the
next scheduled sync let's do it manually
now let's return to the perspective of
the example user
when the user clicks the request
self-service action button they can see
the option to reboot the workspace they
can perform this action without having
to log into AWS the reboot executed
successfully
using this process you can enable your
users to perform different types of
self-service actions from simply
starting and stopping workspaces to
initiating a rebuild action to even more
complex tasks like deploying predefined
software packages
you've just seen how to enable
self-service actions for Amazon
workspaces through ServiceNow
thanks for watching now it's your turn
to try
